title: Elliott Pushes for Polycom-Mitel Tie-up
text:
Activist investor Elliott Management Corp. released a letter Thursday disclosing stakes in Polycom Inc. and Mitel Networks Corp. and urging the telecom companies to merge to increase profitability.
Hedge-fund firm Elliott, founded by Paul Singer, has built a reputation as a bruising investor, willing to pursue activist strategies, protracted litigation and unorthodox tactics.
On Thursday, in its letter addressed to the board of Polycom, Elliott said a merger between the company and Ottawa-based Mitel would "double the scale of Polycom to $2.5 billion in revenue." Elliott added that "it is an attractive strategy, and Polycom is uniquely well-suited for it."
Representatives for Polycom and Mitel didn't immediately respond to a request for comment.
In the note, Elliott disclosed a 6.6% stake in California-based Polycom and pushed it to launch a full strategic review in light of what it deemed as company underperformance.
Elliot disclosed a 6.3% stake in Mitel, saying it is one of the company's biggest stakeholders.
"While company performance has been poor, we think Polycom's CEO Peter Leav and his executive team are quite capable, and this decline demonstrates just how challenging Polycom's end markets are and how necessary it is for the company to take bold action," the letter said.
The letter said that joining Polycom and Mitel was only a starting point with other companies in the sector also potential fits. Elliott said it had conveyed the same proposals to Mitel.
Elliott, viewed as a specialist when it comes to activism in technology companies, has in the past rattled for changes at companies such as Hess Corp., EMC Corp., NetApp Inc. and Interpublic Group of Cos.
Polycom in March agreed to pay the SEC $750,000 to settle civil charges that the tech company had inadequate internal controls and failed to report that a former chief executive used nearly $200,000 of corporate funds for personal perks.
